messages.text:
Is it possible to save the timings of a benchmark and assign a variable within the benchmark at the same time similar to how you can in R? In R I would do
```t <- system.time(x <- rnorm(100000))```
Is there an equivalent using BenchmarkTools? Currently using `a = @benchmarkable rand(100_000); b = run(a)` is the closest I can get, but I can't assign a value to `rand(...)`  using this method.

elements.text: Is it possible to save the timings of a benchmark and assign a variable within the benchmark at the same time similar to how you can in R? In R I would do
t <- system.time(x <- rnorm(100000))
Is there an equivalent using BenchmarkTools? Currently using
a = @benchmarkable rand(100_000); b = run(a)
is the closest I can get, but I can't assign a value to
rand(...)
using this method.

messages.text:
Hi all, does there exist a way to make a base struct reference refer to a specific field?
I want to be able to define a struct as:
```mutable struct Foo
    bar::Any
    fiz::Any
end

instance = Foo(3,"buzz")```
And then default (similarly to overloading Base.getproperty/Base.setproperty!) such that any reference to `instance` is equivalent to `instance.bar`.

instance = Foo(3,"buzz")

messages.text: hello all, I have a dilemma... very frequently I have to make the very hard choice between whether to write some functions for a `Vector{UInt8}` or an `IO`... these are *almost* interchangeable, but an `IO` is a mutable struct and it costs resources to allocate if I want to wrap a `Vector{UInt8}` in an `IOBuffer`.  I often think that I should write everything for `Vector{UInt8}` because of this, but this will assume I can always read in the entire buffer I need first, and indeed in the rare cases when it just can't work this way things can get rather tricky.  Other times, an `IO` actually turns out to be more convenient (particularly because of the `read(io, T)` methods).  Is there some way permanently out of this dilemma of choice?  Am I being ridiculous to worry about the time it takes to allocate an `IO` in IO contexts? (my background is physics so I'm very used to *only* worrying about CPU cycles)

in IO contexts? (my background is physics so I'm very used to
only
worrying about CPU cycles)

messages.text:
I was building a function for `(::Adjoint{SparseMatrixCSC})`. Now when I write it like this -
`f(v::Adjoint{<:SparseMatrixCSC})=f(SparseMatrixCSC(v))`
this gives me an undesired output.
Since there was already a function defined `f(::AbstractArray)`, and `typeof(v')<:AbstractArray => true`.
So it runs the function for this rather than running my defined function for `::Adjoint{<:SparseMatrixCSC}`
How do I get a way around it?

elements.text: I was building a function for
(::Adjoint{SparseMatrixCSC})
. Now when I write it like this -
f(v::Adjoint{<:SparseMatrixCSC})=f(SparseMatrixCSC(v))

this gives me an undesired output.
Since there was already a function defined
f(::AbstractArray)
, and
typeof(v')<:AbstractArray => true

.
So it runs the function for this rather than running my defined function for
::Adjoint{<:SparseMatrixCSC}
How do I get a way around it?

messages.text: I've been thinking a lot lately about how, when compile-time dispatch fails, in maybe 90% of cases the result is simple enough that it can be reduced to a dict lookup, even though this is of course not completely general, but the failure mode, i.e. run-time dispatch, is *much* slower than a dict lookup.  Can the compiler ever be made smart enough to detect the simpler cases, or is there a more fundamental obstacle?

elements.text: I've been thinking a lot lately about how, when compile-time dispatch fails, in maybe 90% of cases the result is simple enough that it can be reduced to a dict lookup, even though this is of course not completely general, but the failure mode, i.e. run-time dispatch, is
much
slower than a dict lookup.  Can the compiler ever be made smart enough to detect the simpler cases, or is there a more fundamental obstacle?

messages.text:
I've been trying to think through what it is I actually enjoy about dynamic programming languages. I'm having a hard time convincing myself that I enjoy them at all, despite using them a lot! Over time, my programming style in dynamic languages has become more and more static, with only small parts requiring true dynamism. This particularly applies as a piece of code transitions from a more researchy state to a more stable, production state.
Does anyone have any clear opinions or thoughts on the benefits? 
Context: I have a good working knowledge of python, Julia, c++, & a few other other static languages.

elements.text:

This particularly applies as a piece of code transitions from a more researchy state to a more stable, production state.
Does anyone have any clear opinions or thoughts on the benefits? 
Context: I have a good working knowledge of python, Julia, c++, & a few other other static languages.

messages.text:
Trying to randomly vary my initial guesses for an optimization to in a way prove that this is the global minima. I have what I think is the global minima. Everything about it is nice, it makes sense in the domain that it's in, and has great confidence intervals.

I have the range where I know the parameters I pass in are realistic.

I'm thinking of having it get optimized, randomly nudged by a certain % and so on and so forth over a certain amount of times all wrapped up in a for loop. Something like this :
```pert = 0.20
IG = IG.*(1 .+ (.- pert .+ 2 .* pert .* rand(-0.5:1e-5:0.5, length(IG))))```
My other idea is to generate all the combinations using the range that I know for each parameter, select a specific amount and have something randomly pick out of those combinations to pass in and optimize the problem.

Any other suggestions would be greatly be appreciated

I was doing some stuff with ranges and I found this behavior kind of odd
```julia> (0:180) .* 40
0:40:7200

julia> 0:180 .* 40
0:7200

julia> 0:180 * 40
0:7200  ```
Why does the `*` operator take precedence over the range one?

messages.text:
I don't really like teaming up with sinners (looking at you engineers) that take pleasure in redefining holy numbers like `π`  to, let's say, `π=3` but can anyone properly explain what is behind the Julia approach that, as long as we don't use `π` we can assign it to something else
```# fire up a new Julias session
π = 3
# Congratulations, Archimedes of Syracuse is now crying```
```# fire up a new Julia session
pi = π
π = 3
# Congratulations, Julia just saved you from hurting Archimedes of Syracuse```
While writing this down I guess I kind of understand the approach, that is, allowing people who don't care what `π` really is being able to not have the symbol locked up to some irrational (pun) nonsense.

But why stop there then? I could be a masochist and not want `(+)`  defined as well...

_1 minute of playing with the REPL later_

HOLY SHIT, if you assign `(+)` before using any `Base` method you can also kill them
```# fire up a new Julia session
(+)(a...) = "nope"

# Congratulations, you have now made all mathematicians cry```
Writing this has been a revelation, I am in awe

messages.text:
What's the motivation to support division of two vectors?
```julia> a = 1:5
1:5

julia> b = 1:5
1:5

julia> a / b
5×5 Matrix{Float64}: ...```
As far as I know, there is no natural definition to divide a vector by another. Julia does the right thing with multiplication: `julia> a * b # results in MethodError`.
Help doesn't explain what this division means:
```help?> /
search: / //

  /(x, y)

  Right division operator: multiplication of x by the inverse of y on the right. Gives floating-point results for integer arguments.

Examples
...```
I'm not aware of any "inverse of a vector", so this description doesn't help.
Looking in the code I see that it treats vectors as single-column matrices and then multiplies `a` by pseudoinverse of `b`. This strongly reminds me of matlab's "everything is a matrix"...

elements.text: What's the motivation to support division of two vectors?

julia> a = 1:5
1:5

julia> b = 1:5
1:5

julia> a / b
5×5 Matrix{Float64}: ...
As far as I know, there is no natural definition to divide a vector by another. Julia does the right thing with multiplication:
julia> a * b # results in MethodError

.
Help doesn't explain what this division means:

help?> /
search: / //

  /(x, y)

  Right division operator: multiplication of x by the inverse of y on the right. Gives floating-point results for integer arguments.

Examples
...

I'm not aware of any "inverse of a vector", so this description doesn't help.
Looking in the code I see that it treats vectors as single-column matrices and then multiplies
a
by pseudoinverse of
b
. This strongly reminds me of matlab's "everything is a matrix"...
There is indeed a somewhat-natural notion of dividing vectors.

messages.text: Lots of people don't like to call it division because it's not unique, and you can get zero for non-zero divisors. But it is *a* inverse to multiplication,  so I don't see what's wrong with it.

messages.text:
In geometric algebra, you'd phrase it this way: define basis vectors `e_1, ... e_n` with a product that has the property `e_i * e_j + e_j  * e_i = δ_ij`. Then if you write
```a = a_1 e_1 + a_2 e_2 + a_3 e_3
b = b_1 e_1 + b_2 e_2 + b_3 e_3```
then if you look at `a/b`, you can write it as
```a / b = a * b / (b * b)
      = a * b / abs2(b)```
in this form, `a * b = a ⋅ b + a ∨ b`  where `⋅` is the normal dot product and `∨`  is the wedge product.

elements.text: In geometric algebra, you'd phrase it this way: define basis vectors
with a product that has the property
e_i * e_j + e_j  * e_i = δ_ij
. Then if you write
then if you look at
a/b
, you can write it as

a / b = a * b / (b * b)
      = a * b / abs2(b)
in this form,
a * b = a ⋅ b + a ∨ b
where
is the normal dot product and
is the wedge product.

messages.text:
Ok, I see that noone else is suprised by vector division and finds it intuitive :)
I was actually caught by this behaviour when julia got killed by OOM. I'm used to multiplication and other math operations like `sin` giving MethodError for vectors - totally makes sense. But division of two vectors tries to create a matrix of size `n x n` which easily exceeds the available memory.

I think this would be useful even for multiplication and other matrix operations. With `A, B` 2d arrays stuff like `A * B` and `exp(A)` would throw an error saying "want elementwise operations? add dot; want matrix operations? do `using LinearAlgebra`"
Of course, this is breaking, if reasonably possible at all...

messages.text:
I'm giving a talk on julia next week to some colleagues.
I've definitely used multiple dispatch a lot, and I fuzzily I recognise that is very useful and natural, but I'm finding it hard to put into words exactly.
Does anyone have any thoughts that could help please, or any links to people who have articulated this well in the past?
I'm also looking at the connection between multiple dispatch and the specialisation system - I feel like there is some "deep" connection there (the two features seem to work very nicely together) - but again, not sure how to quite articulate it.
Thanks in advance!

I'm also looking at the connection between multiple dispatch and the specialisation system - I feel like there is some "deep" connection there (the two features seem to work very nicely together) - but again, not sure how to quite articulate it.
Thanks in advance!

```julia> a = [1 2; 3 4]

ERROR: MethodError: Cannot `convert` an object of type UniformScaling{Int64} to an object of type Float64```

Do we have a periodic vector structure in Base? Something around:
```struct PeriodicVector{T, V <: AbstractVector{T}} # optional but would be cool # <: AbstractVector{T}

    repeat::UInt # 0 => infinite repetition
end```

messages.text: We are planning on building a graphical interface for differential equations.  It seems to us that Julia is the platform for differential equation solvers.  The idea is to build a system of differential equations using a graph representation which then gets translated into a function that can then be evaluated.  Does anyone know about any efforts in this direction?  Can anyone suggest a good starting point for defining and displaying graphs that we can extend for our purpose.  Thanks

elements.text: We are planning on building a graphical interface for differential equations.  It seems to us that Julia is the platform for differential equation solvers.  The idea is to build a system of differential equations using a graph representation which then gets translated into a function that can then be evaluated.  Does anyone know about any efforts in this direction?  Can anyone suggest a good starting point for defining and displaying graphs that we can extend for our purpose.  Thanks

messages.text:
Hey everyone!
I'm having some trouble with structs and am stuck here :disappointed:

I have some code of the following nature:

```struct BlockPartition{Dim,T} <: PartitionMethod
  sides::SVector{Dim,T}
end

BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides)

BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)

function partition(object, method::BlockPartition)
Dim = embeddim(object)
  T = coordtype(object)

  psides = method.sides
  bbox = boundingbox(object)```

Now, I want to add a boolean arguement to the struct. I added a 'neighbors' parameter and came up with this:


```struct BlockPartition{Dim,T,neighbors = false} <: PartitionMethod
  sides::SVector{Dim,T}
  neighbors::Bool
end

BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T},neighbors::Bool) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T,neighbors}(sides)

BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)

function partition(object, method::BlockPartition)
  print("Test string Atreya 123")
  Dim = embeddim(object)
  T = coordtype(object)

  psides = method.sides
  calculate_metadata = method.neighbors
  bbox = boundingbox(object)```

However it doesn't seem to be working. I suspect the problem lies in the following lines:


`BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides)`

`BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)`

However I am not sure how to change them. How can I go about doing this?

elements.text:
Hey everyone!
I'm having some trouble with structs and am stuck here
I have some code of the following nature:

struct BlockPartition{Dim,T} <: PartitionMethod
  sides::SVector{Dim,T}
end

BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides)

BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)

function partition(object, method::BlockPartition)
Dim = embeddim(object)
  T = coordtype(object)

  psides = method.sides
  bbox = boundingbox(object)
Now, I want to add a boolean arguement to the struct. I added a 'neighbors' parameter and came up with this:

struct BlockPartition{Dim,T,neighbors = false} <: PartitionMethod
  sides::SVector{Dim,T}
  neighbors::Bool
end

BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T},neighbors::Bool) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T,neighbors}(sides)

BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)

function partition(object, method::BlockPartition)
  print("Test string Atreya 123")
  Dim = embeddim(object)
  T = coordtype(object)

  psides = method.sides
  calculate_metadata = method.neighbors
  bbox = boundingbox(object)
However it doesn't seem to be working. I suspect the problem lies in the following lines:
BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides)
BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)
However I am not sure how to change them. How can I go about doing this?

messages.text:
can someone help me understand `Threads.Condition`? `Base.Condition` works exactly like I'd expect it to, given the docs, but I don't understand `Threads.Condition` at all.

See for example, the following
```julia
using Base.Threads
using Base.Threads: @spawn, Condition

function f(c::Condition)
    wait(c)
    println("hello f")
end

function g()
    c = Condition()
    lock(c)
    @spawn f(c)
    println("hello g")
    notify(c)
    unlock(c)
end```
This only prints `"hello g"`.  There doesn't seem to be anything I can do to get the condition to stop blocking.

elements.text: can someone help me understand
Threads.Condition
Base.Condition
works exactly like I'd expect it to, given the docs, but I don't understand
Threads.Condition

at all.

See for example, the following

julia
using Base.Threads
using Base.Threads: @spawn, Condition

function f(c::Condition)
    wait(c)
    println("hello f")
end

function g()
    c = Condition()
    lock(c)
    @spawn f(c)
    println("hello g")
    notify(c)
    unlock(c)
end
This only prints
"hello g"
.  There doesn't seem to be anything I can do to get the condition to stop blocking.

messages.text:
4.0KB is pretty good as far as ~Hello world~ fibonacci goes, right?
```julia> using StaticCompiler

julia> fib(n) = n <= 1 ? n : fib(n - 1) + fib(n - 2)
fib (generic function with 1 method)

julia> generate_shlib(fib, (Int,), pwd()*"/fib_static")
("/home/mason/staticplay/fib_static", "fib")

shell> du -h fib_static.so
4.0K    fib_static.so

julia> versioninfo()
Julia Version 1.7.0-DEV.664```

root.text:
So... whats the status on building binaries out of Julia programs?
I've seen PackageCompiler, but the binaries are "big in size". 1.7 is rumored to have better static compilation.... Can we get complete AOT compilation in Julia, in the future？

messages.text: I was actually just thinking the other day about how great a language Julia is for academic writing or note taking - meaning, with tools like `Latexify.jl` and `Literate.jl` and `Weave.jl`, `.jmd` files, Julia's unicode notation, and easy access to the system clipboard or even piping, writing up code ideas becomes a breeze. Sorry to put you on the spot, but I just saw a somewhat unifying package being written by <@U01BTNDCUBX> called `Books.jl` . It looks amazing! Could you talk about it some Rik? Thanks! (link: <https://github.com/rikhuijzer/Books.jl>)

messages.text: How do custom allocators in Julia like <https://github.com/FluxML/Alloc.jl> interact with the GC? For example, is it possible that the GC could walk the stack and follow pointers to structs in the bump-allocated arena while the function is running? I would think that could cause problems. And, if that somehow works, what about references from arena-allocated structs to structs on the main heap, would those main heap structs be properly marked?

elements.text: How do custom allocators in Julia like

interact with the GC? For example, is it possible that the GC could walk the stack and follow pointers to structs in the bump-allocated arena while the function is running? I would think that could cause problems. And, if that somehow works, what about references from arena-allocated structs to structs on the main heap, would those main heap structs be properly marked?
